comments.commentBody:
While I agree with much of what you said, the issue here is different. This is about companies using loopholes in our immigration policy to substitute high wage earners with foreign low-wage earners.

Darwinism, or survival of the fittest as you suggest, does not apply. These workers are not being replaced because their skills diminished, rather, they are being replaced because someone figured out how to manipulate the system to their benefit.

Capitalism should be more like natural selection and less like dog breeding.
Boycott Disney World, Disneyland, Disney stores, Disney cruises, Disney films and all things Disney for this gross injustice to American workers !

or their companies shouldn't be allowed to strip them out with no continual training to keep up w/ tech change. It costs too much, no one else is doing it, and H1B leaves the new employee in their thrall. That's fair, right?

Individuals do not change systems from within. No matter how pure and dedicated. Certainly not systems as corrupt as our political system today.

Changing our political system will have to be forced from the outside, by the voters, the people who are granting our consent to be governed.

Cuomo doesn't like Schneiderman; I don't like Cuomo. Andy's not exactly a "chip off the old block" when it comes to his father.

I keep hoping Andy will go the way of Shelden Silver and the like, at the hands of the Feds and despite a defunct Moreland Commission. Since the term most commonly used to describe NYS government is "dysfunctional", we need the Feds to intercede on our behalf.

Andrew landed too far from Mario's tree.  He lacks the close reasoning, eloquence, and reasoned tact of his father, and presents himself as a hypocritical, self-serving, and blustery bully.  Schneiderman may well be an ambitious politician, but to date he has been more in line with Democratic Party principles than Cuomo Junior ever has been.

Think about it this way - who make the most money from a sick patient?  Answer:  doctors.  Who makes the most money from a healthy patient?  Answer:  insurance companies.  Without insurance companies you'd be paying a heck of a lot more for your healthcare!  Our sytem is Fee For Service, meaning, the more you consume in healthcare, the more money the hospital makes.  The insurance company, as a result, pays for those expenditures.  The insurance company has every incentive to keep the cost of care low.
Can anyone explain what value insurance companies add to the health care system?  Seems to me to make about as much sense a privatizing the fire department.

Yes some of those immigrants were poor and downtrodden, but being downtrodden does not mean being illiterate. A large proportion of Jewish immigrants to this country were utterly impoverished and profoundly gifted. Also, a high proportion of Asains valued education highly.
Indeed some oppressed people did not lower themselves to behave as today's oppressed often feel compelled to do.

What is sad is the fact that the layoffs were a choice--not a necessity. Disney is a fantastically profitable company.  The layoffs were to increase management bonuses and to "reward" shareholders.  We should boycott Disney parks and movies.

Average worker wages and full-time employment will continue to decrease as profits increase.

That's the name of the game!
Here he is folks, the "Rodney Dangerfield" of air travel!

Flying 75,000 miles on Delta is not really what they care about. They only care about how much you spend. For those of us who fly a lot but can't purchase high-end tickets such as international business or first class tickets due to institutional prohibitions on booking anything but economy class, spending $9000 to get to platinum class is very difficult indeed.

In addition Delta makes you purchase everything through them--even tickets on partner airlines. However, Delta doesn't market things like Economy Comfort seats on their partner code-share airlines, so it is an odyssey to try to get these seats involving multiple phone calls and insane monitoring.

Recently I was faced with paying a premium to use my Medallion status on Delta. The lowest fare was reserved for people who wouldn't avail themselves of any Medallion privilege such as a possible upgrade. In effect I was asked to buy a lottery ticket to possibly get an upgrade. It was humiliating, and made me wonder if there was any limit to Delta's greed and desire to insult its best customers.

I live in a Delta hub. I have very little choice about with whom to fly. So I am continually beaten down and made to feel like my loyalty to Delta is only an excuse for them to exploit and denigrate me. I am 6'5" and the few inches of extra legroom are essential for my health (I even have a doctor's orders to this effect), but I get little respect and little cooperation from Delta no matter how much I try to fly with them.

I agree whole-heartedly.  I would only add that if the states of the old Confederacy are ambivalent about secession, they should be expelled.  Like a bad marriage, we have come to the point where we should all recognize that this Union isn't working any more, and we would all be happier if we acknowledged it, and got on with the divorce.  It does not need to be unfriendly, nasty or even unpleasant.  But it is time and past time to split the national sheets.

The NY Times' reporters apparently aren't feeling the economic pinch like a majority of Americans. Maybe they're from very wealthy, entitled families. Maybe they have trust funds. Maybe them make so much they think it's just a "sense" rather than a lived reality. Who knows? The statistics evidently aren't getting through to them, but then again, if you never have to experience others' realities and lack a sense of empathy, perhaps it does all start to feel like perception. Meanwhile, the 99% continue to struggle along. Must be nice to be in an ivory (newsmedia) tower!

Thank you to the New York Times and Julia Preston for reporting on Disney's treatment of its employees. The government will not do anything about the abuse of workers or the visa system until more people are aware of what corporations are doing. This article is proof that we need more excellent and brave journalism to hold corporations and government accountable to the public. I hope the laid off Disney employees land on their feet and find new jobs with better companies than Disney.

The problem is that this support for redistribution is reminiscent of the support for Obamacare before it was implemented. People loved that idea as long as someone else was going to pay for it. In theory, it sounded great. Then the costs to them became known. Suddenly, it became a very bad idea.

They now like the thought of income redistribution as long as the money is flowing from someone else into their pockets. When that income comes out of their pockets, they will be a lot less likely to support redistribution to anyone, no matter how poor.

Let's hope the media does a better job vetting this idea than it did Obamacare. Whose taxes would be raised, specifically? Who would be on the receiving end of that redistributed income? Specifically how would a minimum raise hike affect income level? What would its negative effects be on income, if any? (Please don't call them "unintended" consequences if if they are simply ignored.)

If the CEOs and high paid executives that think cheaper foreign labor is the key to higher profits, I would just ask one question? Once all the jobs have been outsourced who will be left to purchase products a d services? We can all live without Disney and its products, but why no sense of outrage when this happens at companies in various industries across our once great nation as it has been for years? I had a friend who lost her job when the cell phone company she worked for decided to move their call center to India. When is the last time you spoke to an American during a customer service call? Slowly but surely companies are finding the solution to increased profits in laying ppl off. Many of these ppl are at an age where no one is going to hire them, esp not anywhere near their current salaries. How do they pay their mortgage, and their kids college tuition, and afford that nice family vacation to Disneyland or even take their kids to see the latest Disney movie?
Boycott Disney.
Sofia, being from Mexico, you don't need an H1B visa to work here.  You could work here via teh NAFTA agreement.

FINALLY!  This scheme to replace American workers with imported indentured servants has been know for decades but our government has does NOT care about American workers only for American Corporations.

Members of the House and Senate and their counterparts in the 50 states should read this superb article.   Governments have been silent as corporations replace American workers with foreign workers and robots.   But since the corporations fund our representatives and senators, what can we expect?

Its a start, but not the complete solution. Without further reforms, the jobs themselves will just be moved physically overseas. Corporations are spanning geographic boarders and they will just move the job to the location with the most favorable labor laws.

in the mean time, we will have to remain adaptable and look for the growing industries where companies are investing in their business. That could be R/D, Expansion, ect. These companies will pay a premium for good talent because they realize they are an investment. They will actively train their employees, they will compensate them fairly and do everything they can to retain the good talent because its vital to their growth. Corporations with business lines that have matured and they are simply milking the golden goose will take these regressive cost cutting measures because they are making an admission the business is in decline. These cost cutting measures may be implemented to fund a transformation in the business and invest in other business lines that are hiring. They could simply be used to deliver value to the shareholders to prop up the stock price and thus cheap borrowing.

While the corruption needs dealt with and its egregious, we need to remember its our own personal responsibility to keep our skills current and to act proactively when we see the signs. Unfortunately Employment is never guaranteed, save for the rainy day.
Just this morning I was speaking to my daughter about possible trip to a Disney park with our three grandchildren. We will not be going, after reading this. Ever.

To a degree, you may be right about shortage, but saying you had a hard time finding available techies in Silicon Valley is a bit like saying there are not enough women in the Boy Scouts.  It has become its own self fulfilling prophecy.

This is so unacceptable. The fact that Disney, which more than most US companies owes its phenomenal success to the deeply devoted citizens of the US, would remove a high preforming US citizen from their means of making a living in favor of an imported temp is unconscionable. Just think of the positive press they could benefit from ... "We at Disney owe our success to you and your family, so we only employ you and your family."  They've broken the trust. I hope this ends up costing Disney more than it hoped they would save.

You are pretty much full of what these companies tout as teamwork and dedication. While I am older I know quite a few tech workers, my former colleagues in two different Fortune 500 companies, who are in their 40s and have been training foreign workers to replace them. Many of them have had to become independent contractors to stay involved with the industry (electronics). Yes, the companies are simply watching their bottom line as experienced engineers command a higher salary. But better management would take advantage of experienced workers with better efficiency instead of throwing warm bodies at every problem. Lazy management and upside down priorities are the problem, not experienced workers.
